docs.lead_paragraph: Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, one of the nation's biggest and most troubled health insurers, reported yesterday that it had reduced its losses last year and had added substantially to the cash reserves it needs to stay in business. On a more troubling note, Empire, a nonprofit company, said that it continued to lose hundreds of thousands of customers in 1995, pushing down revenues from its main business by $710 million, or 14.7 percent, to $4.09 billion. Much of the lost business was with big companies that switched to insurers offering lower charges and managed care.

headline.main: Empire Blue Cross Reduces Losses and Adds to Reserves

docs.lead_paragraph: Congressional Republicans sought today to reclaim their party's agenda from the rhetoric of its Presidential campaign, insisting that what the economy needed was old-fashioned budget balancing and tax cutting. Congress returned to Washington after a three-week vacation when the Presidential hopefuls from its ranks fared badly in the campaign. But one element of Capitol Hill Republican orthodoxy, tax cuts, seemed sure to survive both the upsets of the primaries and the new political buzzwords of "layoffs" and "corporate responsibility."

headline.main: Still Talking About Tax Cuts, Congress Goes Back to Work

docs.lead_paragraph: Her nimble fingers dance across the red felt semicircle, dealing cards and sweeping up chips. She calculates at lightning speed, rewarding good luck with more chips, and grimacing as she cleans out a loser. Jan Craven is a blackjack dealer aboard the Northern Star riverboat casino, one of two owned by Harrah's Entertainment that ply one and one-half miles of a canal through industrial wasteland, satisfying a state requirement that gambling take place only offshore. "She's got personality, personality," chants Mike Jones, a tavern owner from Indiana who has amassed a $980 stack of chips as tall as his rum and Coke.

headline.main: Portrait From New Era Of Nation's Gambling

docs.lead_paragraph: Judging from the raucous scene at its front gate, Barnard College resembled an auto plant far more than an ivory tower yesterday as dozens of striking workers carried picket signs, blew whistles and implored students and professors to honor their picket line. The 150 striking clerical workers, library workers and dormitory desk attendants found a sympathetic audience. By faculty estimates, about half of professors held classes off campus to avoid crossing the picket line.

headline.main: Picket Line at Barnard Is Test in Class Struggle 101

docs.lead_paragraph: In a dispute that legal and medical experts say is both highly unusual and indicative of gray areas in New York State law, administrators at a Queens hospital have said they will go to court today for permission to remove a 5-month-old girl from a ventilator against her parents' wishes. Administrators at the hospital, Long Island Jewish Medical Center, said in a statement released yesterday that the baby, Mariah Scoon, was determined to have no evidence of brain function and pronounced dead early last week. They said she was allowed to remain on a ventilator for several days afterward at the request of her parents, Malcolm and Lois Scoon of Jamaica, Queens.

headline.main: A Hospital Goes to Court Over a Baby

docs.lead_paragraph: SOME people will go to any lengths to avoid paying taxes. Lewis J. Altfest, a fee-only financial planner in Manhattan, recalls a client who insisted on investing in municipal bonds rather than higher-yielding Treasuries because the interest was tax-free. The woman, who would have made more money buying Treasuries even after paying taxes, did not care about the lower returns -- she wanted to owe the Government as little as possible. "People get more satisfaction in saving on their taxes than just the amount of money," Mr. Altfest said. No matter that a fat refund check is more a symbol of poor tax planning than of victory. "You've bested the Government," he said.

headline.main: Deducting Everything While You Still Can

docs.lead_paragraph: No matter how daunting a tax return may look, it is essentially based on two sets of numbers: income and deductions. Overlook any income -- say reinvested mutual fund dividends -- and the I.R.S. is likely to demand its due. Overlook any deductions, and you won't hear a peep, but you'll overpay your taxes. A tax professional or a good computer program can put the numbers in the right places on the forms, but it is up to the taxpayer to provide all the numbers. To guide taxpayers through the process, that is learn just what numbers are needed and how finances can be structured to take advantage of the tax breaks available, Jan M. Rosen of The New York Times used the CD-ROM version of Turbo Tax in consultation with Mark R. Goines, vice president and general manager of the personal tax group of Intuit, which publishes Turbo Tax, and Guy D. MacNeill, group product manager for Turbo Tax, to prepare this return for a hypothetical two-income New York family.

headline.main: A Step-by-Step Guide to Mastering the Form 1040

docs.lead_paragraph: RANDY RYAN flies DC-10's for United Airlines, but his wife, Pam, has put their money on autopilot. When they take a six-week vacation in Australia this spring, a computer banking service will make sure their bill payments depart and arrive on time. "We will be able to schedule the rent and utilities to be paid," said Mrs. Ryan, a philosophy graduate student who signed up for the service at a Citibank branch near her home in Chicago. "And since we will take my laptop with us, we'll be able to check on the accounts while we are away."

headline.main: Banking at Home: Once More, With Feeling

docs.lead_paragraph: EVAN KENNEDY started smoking when he was 12 years old. All his friends smoked; it seemed like the cool thing to do. At first, he said, he liked the idea. But now, at the age of 15, the Milford boy is having second thoughts. Back when he started, he didn't need to smoke; he just lit up when he felt like it. "But then it got like you had to go out and have a cigarette or have one as soon as you got off the school bus and I got kind of addicted to it," he said. Although he still likes to smoke, he often wishes he had never started.

docs.lead_paragraph: FIVE years ago a young man from Mexico City who identified himself as Juan left his family and illegally crossed the border to the United States. With no prospects of earning a living and with a wife and two children to feed, he hoped to find a better life here. Instead of heading toward California like most Mexican immigrants, Juan traveled to join his brother-in-law on the South Fork, where he was immediately employed as a painter.

headline.main: Hispanic Population Making Inroads on the South Fork
